docs.lead_paragraph: WorldCom's downfall is swelling the exodus of workers from the telecommunications industry, which alone has accounted for more than one out of every 10 jobs lost in the United States since the recession began in March last year. Most of this rapid job shrinkage in telecommunications has come through layoffs, buyouts and forced retirements. Indeed, telecommunications companies have exceeded any other industry in the number of publicly announced job cuts over the last 18 months.

headline.main: Job Cuts Take Heavy Toll on Telecom Industry
headline.kicker: TURMOIL AT WORLDCOM: THE WORK FORCE

docs.abstract: Exodus of workers from telecommunications industry swells as companies cut labor force by laying off or buying out workers and forcing retirements; industry accounts for 167,000 jobs cuts, over ten percent of lost jobs in nation since recession began in Mar 2001; industry analysts believe that elimination of another ten percent of industry's employees is required and that no rehiring will be necessary when economy rebounds; graphs; photographs (M)
